<@U8C8E99B5> why tf anyways? IMHO the abstractions are giving you nothing because you have to make it cloud vendor specific anyways. We use a wrapper around cloudformation called senza, I am not sure if I would recommend it, but I can in general recommend cloudformation. Kops has a good setup for creating clusters, but it uses aws api calls and I am not sure how people update their clusters with it and if it is reliable in case of ratelimits from aws api....
It will also normally automatically refresh itself
<@U26AMEVAS> no there is no way to increase rate limits in AWS

<@U1DD4AZND> the problem is that they don’t use cloudformation. We built, maintain and use <https://github.com/zalando-incubator/kube-ingress-aws-controller> in combination with skipper in production in 50 clusters since 1 year
<@U4BFPGKV4> I would not run it as daemonset, but maybe you can try one replica per ASG. I think we (Mikkel, you and me) already discuss this in the GH issues, right?

<@U26AMEVAS> our setup is ALB -> skipper ingress -> svc -> pods, works good for us. ALB does TLS termination. Our ALB controller creates shared ALBs per certificate. Like this we have much less rate limit problems. Only for heavy use of statefulsets we have problems with rate limits.

```
apiVersion: batch/v2alpha1
kind: CronJob
metadata:
  name: kube-gelf-reload-config
  namespace: kube-system
spec:
  successfulJobsHistoryLimit: 1
  failedJobsHistoryLimit: 1
  schedule: “*/30 * * * *”
  jobTemplate:
    spec:
      template:
        spec:
          serviceAccountName: kube-gelf
          containers:
          - name: cron
            image: <http://gcr.io/google_containers/hyperkube-amd64:v1.7.5|gcr.io/google_containers/hyperkube-amd64:v1.7.5>
            args:
            - /bin/sh
            - -c
            - for POD in `kubectl get pod --namespace kube-system -l app=kube-gelf | tail -n +2 | awk '{print $1}'`; do echo RELOAD ${POD}; kubectl exec --namespace kube-system ${POD} -- /bin/sh -c ‘kill -1 1’; done
          restartPolicy: OnFailure
```

`Starting and stopping pods may introduce noise to the metric (for instance, starting may temporarily increase CPU). So, after each action, the autoscaler should wait some time for reliable data. Scale-up can only happen if there was no rescaling within the last 3 minutes. Scale-down will wait for 5 minutes from the last rescaling. Moreover any scaling will only be made if: avg(CurrentPodsConsumption) / Target drops below 0.9 or increases above 1.1 (10% tolerance). Such approach has two benefits:`

<@U4T5K4ND9> yes…ish. So, we were running k8s 1.8.1 with etcd 3.0.17 (and 3.0.25) of which both versions of etcd were problematic with the same symptoms. Some folks in our office were running k8s 1.8.2 with etcd 3.0.17 and having no issues. I updated my cluster to k8s 1.8.2 and etcd 3.0.29 and we’ve not experienced the issue since. So we are thinking the problem wasn’t etcd, but k8s 1.8.1.

at first we thought that it might have been because we were using an unsanctioned version of etcd with 1.8.x. The sanctioned IE tested version is 3.0.17, but I just had a minimal cluster die last night while using 3.0.17 — although I failed to check the file descriptor usage so this issue might be a different one. In order to do this properly, you'd need to understand all of the pods/LBs/volumes/DNS deployed in your cluster as X and then Y/X where your namespace is Y. No <@U0TTN7UR2>, Actually I am getting the logs from journald on Kibana, and now I want kube components logs in openshift (like somehow I can get it in journald). Please suggest me how can I do this.

<@U0B2WM5PT> Records read from the journal are initially tagged with 'journal' <https://github.com/openshift/origin-aggregated-logging/blob/master/fluentd/generate_throttle_configs.rb#L134>

These records are then retagged, primarily for kubernetes processing: <https://github.com/openshift/origin-aggregated-logging/blob/master/fluentd/configs.d/openshift/filter-retag-journal.conf>
If this is a record from journal, which is not from a container, then it will be retagged with 'journal.system': <https://github.com/openshift/origin-aggregated-logging/blob/master/fluentd/configs.d/openshift/filter-retag-journal.conf#L75>

# not kubernetes - assume a system log
  rewriterule9 _TRANSPORT .+ journal.system

so you probably want to have something like this:

   <match journal.system>
      @type rewrite_tag_filter
      rewriterule1 _SYSTEMD_UNIT ^origin-master.service journal.system.kubernetes.master
      rewriterule2 _SYSTEMD_UNIT ^origin-node.service journal.system.kubernetes.node
      rewriterule3 _TRANSPORT .+ journal.system # there is no default rule, and there is no way to say "no match, just pass through" - you have to match and rewrite _everything_ unfortunately

Still wondering about this part of the outline in <https://github.com/kubernetes/kops/blob/master/docs/boot-sequence.md#node-bringup> : “kubelet will start up, and will kube-proxy. It will try to reach the api-server on the internal DNS name, and once the master is up it will succeed”.  What makes that internal DNS name resolve before the kubelets contact the apiserver to say they can run DNS pods?

I was reading <https://github.com/kubernetes/kops/blob/master/docs/philosophy.md> and noticed something that might be a typo.  Is this the right channel to ask about it?

I read “if you don’t want to override the default value, you simply specify the fields”.  Was the word “don’t” accidentally omitted from the last clause?

It looks to me like there is a circular dependency in kops.  The internal components are configured to reach the k8s apiserver at `<http://api.internal.mycluster.com|api.internal.mycluster.com>`.  That is resolved by kube’s DNS application, which runs in pods after the kubelets and kube-proxy are up.  But the kubelets and kube-proxy need that domain name working before they can come up.

<@U0EAYQ3LG> <@U45JX5RPA> <@U0YJS6LHL> Thanks, I think we have (hopefully) pinned this down to a network issue; the masters were unreachable by ~80% of our nodes for a period of about 15 minutes, so they marked the nodes as `NotReady` after the grace period. As far as I can see k8s was behaving correctly. We probably want to tune the grace period but we’re obviously trading off “reaction time” for a genuine node failure. I wonder if rate limiting on this would be a good idea – it doesn’t seem likely to ever be a good thing to evict ~80% of pods at once.

For background, Go's OAuth2 library doesn't send the client credentials as part of the POST body, since that's what that RFC recommends:

<https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-2.3.1>
>    Including the client credentials in the request-body using the two
>   parameters is NOT RECOMMENDED and SHOULD be limited to clients unable
>   to directly utilize the HTTP Basic authentication scheme (or other
>   password-based HTTP authentication schemes).

I'm using Azure as the infrastructure provider for the cluster. We need to whitelist the cluster on services outside cluster (like databases etc.) and so we need the public IP of cluster.
In Azure (we have noticed), this public IP of cluster is the LoadBalancer's public IP created when we deployed Nginx Ingress Controller.
This was true till the time we had just one service of type LoadBalancer, but recently some new folks using the cluster deployed another service of type LoadBalancer and it somehow changed the public IP of cluster to the new service's LB IP.
We are just trying to prevent this from happening again. In our design, the pods/services/apps should be accessible via ingress controller.
aha, that seems like it will make things easier. Thanks <@U37TLLWAU>

We're facing an issue with authorization mode "allow all" and some manifests that uses RBAC resources.

As far as we understood, the RBAC API is enabled by default but not the RBAC authorizer (<https://github.com/kubernetes/features/issues/2#issuecomment-330569468>).

So a manifest using RBAC resources should works (RBAC API would create unused stuff as there is not the RBAC authorizer to use them).

But we get a message "<http://clusterroles.rbac.authorization.k8s.io|clusterroles.rbac.authorization.k8s.io> "xxx" is forbidden: attempt to grant extra privileges" like there is an authorizer doing its authorization job (but we're yet using the flag `--authorization-mode=AlwaysAllow`).

Does one have an idea about it ? do we miss something ? or is that some kind of bug with authz system ?
(or having rook finally use something like <https://github.com/rook/rook/pull/1231/files>)

`for roles, it still just checks if you already have all the RBAC permissions of the role you are creating/updating, with no fallback to ask the current authorizer if you have permission (since there's not a succinct way to ask the authorizer about potentially dozens of different permissions at once)` if I understand it right, that means to get such thing working without using RBAC authorizer it would require a  kind of "RBAC bootstraping" whicih will grant RBAC permissions on the used user and then that would works
thx a lot ) will RTFM that link you sent me :slightly_smiling_face:
and <https://github.com/rook/rook/blob/40d129d2e0c32af5234dee97cbcf4259862a9fd0/pkg/operator/agent/agent.go#L83>
`--authorization-mode=AlwaysAllow` doesn't means only RBAC API is used and not the RBAC authorizer ?
and also I'll then be able to provide feedback on <https://github.com/rook/rook/issues/1221> :wink:
so I believe the only way to get it working without enabling RBAC authorizer is to grant permissions to the used user before running that rook stuff
anyway, we're going to add RBAC like.. now.. but still interesting to know how it goes under the hood )

Nabend, zufällig bin ich gerade auch mit dem Thema beschäftigt.
Zum einen kannst du eine Statusseite aktivieren, in der configmap `enable-vts-status: 'true'` hinzufügen, dann ist die Statuseite unter `<nginx-ip>:18080/nginx_status` erreichbar. Das ganze als JSOn unter `/nginx_status/format/json`.
Und um den in Prometheus hinzuzufügen, kannst exemplarisch sowas verwenden (in dem Beispiel ist der K8s Api Server noch unter einem insecuren port erreichbar):
```  - job_name: 'nginx-ingress-controller'
    kubernetes_sd_configs:
    - role: pod
      api_server: http://<apiserver-ip>:8080
    relabel_configs:
    - source_labels: [__meta_kubernetes_pod_label_app]
      action: keep
      regex: nginx-ingress-lb
    - source_labels: [__address__]
      action: replace
      regex: ([^:]+)(?::\d+)?
      replacement: $1:10254
      target_label: __address__
    - action: labelmap
      regex: __meta_kubernetes_pod_label_(.+)
    - source_labels: [__meta_kubernetes_namespace]
      action: replace
      target_label: kubernetes_namespace
    - source_labels: [__meta_kubernetes_pod_name]
      action: replace
      target_label: kubernetes_pod_name
    - source_labels: [__meta_kubernetes_pod_ip]
      action: replace
      target_label: kubernetes_pod_ip
    - source_labels: [__meta_kubernetes_pod_node_name]
      action: replace
      target_label: kubernetes_pod_node_name
```

those kind of tests say nothing…you can simply ask questions related to the person experience in the CV.
Give them hypothetical situations and see how he/she reacts and what is his/hers thought process
Ask normal kubernetes questions:
 - How do you deploy a cluster?
 - What is the difference between a pod and a node and a container? (you will be amazed how many people claim to use k8s but have no idea what is the difference)
 - What is a ConfigMap?
 - How are the secrets encrypted ? Is it safe for let’s say a public cluster?
 - What k8s version have you deployed?
 - how big was the cluster you maintained?
 - What kind of automation have you used to deploy k8s and why?
 - Selfhosted k8s or run it as a service? Why?
 - Selfhosted etcd or standalone cluster? What if we want to have cross DC failover?
 - Ansible vs Puppet/Chef/SaltStack
 - Terraform vs Ansible/Puppet/Chef/Puppet/SaltStack
 - Container vs Vm
 - When DNS traffic is not UDP?
 - How would you update from k8s 1.5 to 1.8?
I want to see that they at least understand the moving parts of k8s because to deploy on it is a easyish process

Ultimately it depends on the client base, the extent of k8s in production (devOps resumes outnumber those with true k8s prod experience) and your sales/bizdev leadership.  You may be underselling yourselves at $50-60/hr; we don’t have clients in Israel.  It’s also imperative to promote architecture over engineering as you pitch; a good architect will reduce the long-term need for good engineers.  Lastly, you will only ever get paid what you ask for or require.  If you are in demand, it’s a seller’s market.  Best of luck.

Thank you for the link, <@U7TEUTUMU>.  Important to note is that the probationary period is a two-party event.  For employees, if a company cannot determine your trustworthiness quickly, and you feel, as an individual under evaluation, that it’s not a good fit, consider that strongly if/when the period completes.  For employers, if you struggle to get organic buy-in from the majority of your contributors, remote or otherwise, you may need to analyze your incentives (they may not always be obvious).  Changing culture is hard from both ends; yet we collectively work in the cloud, which by definition, is a time, not a place.

Perhaps we should pin an approved definition of remote to the channel?  
> Remote is defined as working local hours from anywhere in the world 95% of the time.  Roughly 13 days of the year, attendance in the local office is expected for a 250 day work year.  Determining whether the in-office days are reimbursed would be a consideration between employer and employee.
That can be a tough call.  If existing, you may find you’re contributing more than if nascent, depending on the skillset of the original SRE/architect.

It has received 5 unsolicited approvals, 4 in the form of “thumbs up”, and one comment.  Beyond that, I simply shared what I tell everyone when discussing remote offerings.  We also recognize the value of working out of the office, and adjust offers accordingly.
Not sure why it would be perceived of as anything but real.  It’s a big range.
<@U2D2RBJ8M> It’s a range based on deliverables, from designing a new deployment to production support.  We have charged (and received) from $195/hr to $295/hr.

It’s a fast-moving technology, with the most-skilled focusing on improving the FOSS.  It’s a tough balance between contributions (which don’t pay) and deployments/support, which can.  That being said, pro bono for a worthwhile startup is always in consideration as well.  It’s a new frontier.

Hi everyone,

We have an opening for a Kubernetes SME to work with us here at Contino (<http://www.contino.io|www.contino.io>).

12 week initial engagement in Germany. 

In short; his project is about enabling AWS consumption using automation and also helping with Kubernetes PaaS using giantswarm.

A key initiative in achieving efficiency and speed in the SDLC is our customers platform. This is a cloud based 'Platform As A Service' which makes it simpler and faster to develop digital consumer facing applications.

We are engaged as an advisory and delivery partner to support the build of the platforms initiative. This would involve contributing to the build of the platform best practices for automation and operability, but also support on-boarding onto the platform whilst also up-skilling and training our customers staff in parallel.

We are tasked with developing an internal AWS capability and remove the reliance on a third party vendor. We are also tasked with looking to teach our customer to understand AWS best practices, using automation and federated access to controlled environments.

As well as insourcing a best practice AWS implementation, our team have identified the value of software containerisation based on Docker and Kubernetes. The customer will require training and upskilling in containers and Kubernetes as they begin consuming and moving workloads onto the platform.

Sorry for the long winded explanation - but I wanted to give you all a good idea of the project. 

We require someone to start with us prior to the 5th July 2017 - if possible to be UK based consultant willing to travel to Germany.

Please contact me directly on DM or at <mailto:alex.jones@contino.io|alex.jones@contino.io>

Many thanks!! 
Alex

Hi everyone!

We're looking for somebody in EU to help us respond to possible downtimes of our cluster + improve it by adding better monitoring/alerts, autoscaling, etc..

The reason we're looking for a sysadmin in EU is that half of our customers are there and we are located in San Francisco so if our app goes down when we sleep it's pretty bad for them. They also use our product 8-9h a day so downtimes are really not desirable and is a big problem for us. Enough to look for a freelance sysadmin :slightly_smiling_face:

Here's what I'm thinking you could help us in the first period with:

- Migrate us completely to helm (we've already done it with one our sites), but the main product is still using a combination of replication controllers/services. We want to use helm so that we can have an easier deployment of another staging cluster for example or do tenant isolation.
- Setup a monitoring/alerts for our services. Currently our stack is comprised of a uWSGI python server, flask-socketio, celery workers, rabbitmq cluster and 2 prostgres instances. The alerts should be a bit more based on the load of those services rather than simple up/down state.
- Setup autoscaling for our workers (web and celery) so that they scale according to traffic/rabbitmq available messages in certain queues. At first only k8s autoscaling, then we might launch additional nodes on the cluster too, but that's latter on and not a priority for now.

FYI: we're on GCP using their hosted k8s.

Once we've done all that we'd like to have somebody on pager duty during the day (8h). We're essentially looking to cover the european timezone as much as we can just in case there is something bad going on.

If you're interested send me an email: <mailto:alex@gorgias.io|alex@gorgias.io>

no.

it depends on how you deploy or change the service, but generally speaking it is smart. if you do a `kubectl replace` or a `kubectl delete` then `kubectl create`, then it deletes the elb and recreates a new one. if you do a `kubectl edit` or `patch`, then it will only change things it needs leaving the existing elb up while doing it.
yes it's by design, there is no easy way to control it.

The threat model in a container is a bit different than in a traditional Linux distro: with containers, the author of the container image define the binaries with file capabilities and/or setuid. So it is a more controlled environment of what binaries are available, compared to a traditional Linux distro where there are a lot of setuid programs that can be tricked into believing setuid() syscall succeeded.

Hello, we are currently having an issue with kubernetes/etcd combined with rkt. 
When a pod fail it reboots with an different uuid, resulting in several events.
<https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/5f9f4a1c5939436fa320e9bc5973a55d6446e59f/pkg/kubelet/rkt/rkt.go#L1306>
As it's occurs only 1 time it creates one key in etcd and doesn't stack because of the uuid.
As a result if a pod keep failing it creates thousands of new keys in etcd. Ending up in millions keys if several are failing.
We end up with a database with more than 2gb of data and we trigger the "db size alarm".
How could we fix this appart from fixing pods itself? Thanks in advance for the answer.
But we thought that we could do a PR instead of doing our own patch.

I have some *old* rkt deployments with the `--mds-register`. Inside the container, apps reach the host IP with the environment variable e.g: `AC_METADATA_URL=<http://172.16.28.1:18112/uuid>` to use host-network services.
Today with our rktnetes setup, the `--mds-register` flag is missing but this feature is obviously replaced by the k8s downward API.
But, currently, Kubernetes doesn't allow to set the field `status.hostIP`: <https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/ee255d09fa3fd84756bf51c8d0c130ea2af456f2/pkg/api/validation/validation.go#L1419>

About the design of logging - I'm thinking about two options:

- adding a new binary in stage1 which will convert stdout and stderr streams to CRI format - ttyomux creates sockets in `/var/lib/rkt/pods/<pod_id>/stage1/rootds/rkt/iottymux/<app_name>` directory and the filenames are `stdout.sock` and `stderr.sock` - I imagine that the separate binary will read lines from those sockets, convert each of them to CRI format and then save it to the logfile

- writing CRI logs in `ttyomux` (that implementation was already started, but it's not finished yet) to the logfile

Both solutions will require changes in rkt, not rktlet. Also, since kubelet only assumes that the runtime will write logs to the specified file, we are thinking about mounting `/var/log/pods/<podUID>/` directory into the stage1 and then our new binary will write CRI-compatible logs there. That mount can be handled by systemd-nspawn/machinectl arguments which we pass in rkt when creating stage1 - this can be done by a CLI argument or option.
if we will learn ttyomux to write CRI logs to an another file/socket, it will be available on the host too

  --mount volume=container-logs,target=/var/log/containers \

ExecStart=/usr/lib/coreos/kubelet-wrapper \

  --pod-manifest-path=/etc/kubernetes/manifests \
  --allow-privileged=true \

  --serialize-image-pulls=false \

ExecStop=-/usr/bin/rkt stop --uuid-file=/var/run/kubelet-pod.uuid

<@U4QFZFMCM> Running pylint on prow is actually pretty hard. We can do golint as a plugin because it doesn't actually run any of the code in the presubmit. Pylint does, so we don't want to be running it in a trusted environment. However, in order to leave reviews we need a github api token. This means that a proper prow pylint thing needs to spawn the pylint runner in an untrusted place, read the results somehow, and then leave the comment.

The differences it produces are specific to the structures `<http://k8s.io/apimachinery/pkg/apis/meta/v1.Duration|k8s.io/apimachinery/pkg/apis/meta/v1.Duration>`, `<http://k8s.io/apimachinery/pkg/apis/meta/v1.MicroTime|k8s.io/apimachinery/pkg/apis/meta/v1.MicroTime>`, and `<http://k8s.io/apimachinery/pkg/apis/meta/v1.Time|k8s.io/apimachinery/pkg/apis/meta/v1.Time>`. Our code copies over all of our vendor dependencies into a temporary dir and exports GOPATH to point to it before executing `openapi-gen`. it is really dirty:  ```#!/bin/bash
# this runs the login command and drops all of the bits into an array
read -r -a login_info <<< $(aws --profile bns --region us-east-1 ecr get-login)

USER="${login_info[3]}"
PASSWORD="${login_info[5]}"
EMAIL="${login_info[7]}"
SERVER="${login_info[8]}"

kubectl delete secret aws-ecr-credentials
kubectl create secret docker-registry aws-ecr-credentials \
    --docker-server=${SERVER} \
    --docker-username=${USER} \
    --docker-password=${PASSWORD} \
    --docker-email=${EMAIL}
```

You need a level 4 proxy to get it working if i am not wrong. But from my point of view i would suggest to use a load balancer with an additional security group. ```<http://service.beta.kubernetes.io/aws-load-balancer-extra-security-groups|service.beta.kubernetes.io/aws-load-balancer-extra-security-groups>: "sg-someid123"``` and ```  loadBalancerSourceRanges:
    - 127.0.0.1/32```- This will allow you to configure ips/sg access through terraform (if you manage the security group through terraform of course :D) and even allows you to use security group whitelistening which works better then ip whitelistening.
<@U8FBUBBC3> - Cluster do not have --subnet as cli argument. Only Instance Group creation has it. - e.g. ``` kops create ig --name somename prometheus --subnet eu-west-1a``` would work

Hi guys, my cluster is quite stable once it has started, but starting up can be quite difficult. Most of my pods are Java application and when they boot up they eat a lot of CPU. so when I start my cluster, all the pods compete for CPU; I can see the CPU going to 100% in cloudwatch (4 x m3.large slaves). That means that each pod is slower to start that it normally would, which in turn means they do not get ready fast enough for the life probes.  So they get killed and restarted, going into an endless cycle of CPU feast. Of course I could increase the `initialDelay` on the probs, but then it means I have to wait too long for the pod to be healthy when I do a deployment (and the cluster is not so stressed). Has anyone had this problem? are there strategies to mitigate it? It would be great if there was an option to tell k8s to initially start one pod at the time rather than trying to start them all at once.

<@U3GBB923B> thank you so much for the help, I finally found it, and it was rather insidious.  I am using Rancher to provision k8s automatically on the hosts as they're spun up, and it works beautifully, however I mistakenly had forgotten to disable the Rancher "ingress controller", which runs out-of-band outside the cluster and manipulates ingress resources via the API.  So every time the nginx ingress controller updated the ingress, the Rancher one would reset it. :angry: 

Anyways, all fixed now and things are running beautifully - thanks again!

Some issues with the two existing TF configurations and kops:

Tectonic
  - lots of stuff related to tectonic that's unnecessary
  - "self-hosted kubernetes" - not sure the implications of doing this
  - no built-in way to launch additional minion pools

tack
  - does PKI with cfssl on an EC2 instance, seems to store CA cert on the instance storage
  - does not run in HA (does not distribute etcd across multiple AZs)
  - runs etcd and master nodes on the same node (so what happens to etcd when you upgrade k8s)
  - does not run "self-hosted k8s", so what's the implication of an upgrade?

kops
  - from what I understand, integration with terraform is weak, meaning if we needed to launch a new cluster, it would involve running the kops CLI, not copying .tf configuration

```
kubectl create serviceaccount travis
TOKEN=$(kubectl get secret `kubectl get serviceaccounts travis -o=jsonpath='{$.secrets[:1].name}'` -o jsonpath='{$.data.token}')
```

Car j'ai une question sur les bonnes partiques. Je travaille sur plusieurs cluster (dev-staging-prod) et je crée des packages Helm que j'installe dessus. Si j'ai bien compris la philosophie de HELM, l'objectif est de créer le package une seule fois et de le déployer sur mes différents environnements. Mais arrive la question de la config et du coup de la meilleure façon d'y répondre : Est-ce que vous gérez la config via des ConfigMaps déployées dans chaque environnement ou bien vous surchargez cette config au moment de l'installation du package (via helm install toto -f config.yaml ou --set)?
J'aime bien l'idée que mon Package soit complètement "agnostique" de sa configuration, mais je ne sais pas quelle est la meilleure façon de lui "injecter" cette config. Ou alors il y a une 3ème voie que je n'ai pas vu.
Merci à vous

<@U1RUZHYKH> : Vous archivez donc les deployment.yaml et les service.yaml c'est ça?
<@U47FZKWLR> : c'est compliqué pour nous d'avoir un cycle de vie commun car les différents services sont développés par des équipes différentes.

Bonjour,
Y a-t-il un moyen de versionner l'état global d'un namespace? Je m'explique : si je crée un namespace "Project-A-Prod" dans lequel j'ai 3 déploiements ServiceA (v1.0.0), ServiceB(v1.5.6) et ServiceC(v2.0.1). Au fil des mises à jours, chaque service vit sa vie et arrive un moment où j'aurais peut-être besoin de rollback l'ensemble de ces 3 services dans un état précédent. Je pose cette question car dans le monde de docker-compose, on peut archiver le fichier docker-compose qui pointe sur des versions bien spécifiques des services. J'ai une pseudo notion de "stack" que je n'ai plus dans kubernetes. Est-ce quelque chose qu'il faut que je maintienne moi même dans une base à part? Où bien K8S gère les choses complètement différemment?
Je ne trouve pas de bonnes pratiques à ce sujet.
Merci à vous
oui oui, comme dans rancher en fait.

<@U6SAT4Z19>: Chez nous aussi, on a un système similaire dans lequel on utilise le K/V store de Consul pour stocker la config, mais on est quand même obligé de "seter" une variable d'environnement (dev, staging, prod) pour dire à l'app de charger la bonne config. C'est cette variable d'environnement que je pense modifier à l'installation de mon package Helm via `-f config.yaml` (entre autres choses)

bonjour, J'ai une question peut-être un peu naïve, mais enfin ... Je suis nouveau sur Kubernetes, mais j'utilise Rancher depuis 2 ans. Pour ceux qui connaissent, Rancher propose la notion de stack dans laquelle on déploie des services. Une stack est en fait un fichier docker-compose. Si j'ai par exemple un fichier docker-compose avec un service Redis, une base mongoDB et un frontal NodeJS, j'aurais une stack Rancher avec 3 services à l'intérieur (Redis, Mongo et nodejs).

Avec K8S je vais avoir un service Mongo, un service Redis et un service Nodejs qui vont cotoyer d'éventuels d'autres services. 
Alors c'est sans doute "psycho" mais j'ai l'impression qu'avec K8S tout est en vrac directement à la racine du namespace.

D'après ce que je comprends de K8S, la notion "englobante" des pods est le "service". Mais il n'y a rien  au dessus.

Du coup, y a t-il des bonne pratique pour la gestion des namespace et du nommage des services?

J'aimais bien l'approche ConfigMaps aussi pour gérer la config de mon app, mais elle doit exister dans chaque environnement *avant* d'installer le package. Avec le `-f config.yaml` ça a l'avantage de se faire lors de l'installation et le package reste dissocié de la conf.
J'ai peut-être une piste : <https://icicimov.github.io/blog/virtualization/Kubernetes-shared-storage-with-S3-backend/>
J'ai eu une réponse qui me conforte dans ce que je pensais :
Coucou, y-a-t'il des utilisateurs de HELM par ici?
<@U47FZKWLR> : sympa helm! Merci, je ne connaissais pas encore.

Actuellement, avec Rancher, nous avons l'équivalent d'un namespace "production" et un autre "developpement". Dans chacun de ces namespaces on trouve plusieurs stacks avec des microservices à l'intérieur. Et certaines stacks peuvent communiquer les unes avec les autres.
Du coup, si je me projette avec Kubernetes, un pattern envisageable serait d'avoir un namespace par stack donc?

After spending some time hacking around and trying various things, I haven't yet found a decent way to get kompose to 1) use persistent data on AWS (the volumes always get deleted with `kompose down`, and 2) exposing a service using ALB (although I've gotten this working using alb-ingress-controller and a small Ingress yaml file)
I might be missing something, but AFAICT it seems perfectly reasonable to have a setup where some storage is mounted on each node in a cluster and then `hostPath` can do the right thing
Then perhaps what's needed is just recognising if there is a path in the `kompose.service.expose` attribute and adding an additional bit to the Ingress created.

```apiVersion: extensions/v1beta1
kind: Ingress
metadata:
  name: "my-alb-ingress"
  annotations:
    <http://alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/scheme|alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/scheme>: internet-facing
    <http://alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/subnets|alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/subnets>: 'subnet-xxx, subnet-yyyy'
    <http://alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/security-groups|alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/security-groups>: sg-ggg
    <http://kubernetes.io/ingress.class|kubernetes.io/ingress.class>: "alb"
  labels:
    app: myservice-alb-ingress
spec:
  rules:
  - host: <http://myhost.com|myhost.com>
    http:
      paths:
      - path: /foo
        backend:
          serviceName: "myservice"
          servicePort: 80
```
The storage can be easily set up like that to be from EBS, GCS, nfs, etc.
